key_findings: Utilize AWS S3 or Google Cloud Storage for scalable and reliable image storage solutions. Both platforms offer robust APIs for easy integration.
Implement lazy loading for images to improve page load times and enhance user experience. Use the 'loading' attribute in the tag or JavaScript libraries to defer loading off-screen images.
Consider using WebP format for images to reduce file size without sacrificing quality. This can lead to faster loading times and reduced bandwidth usage.
When processing images, leverage libraries like Sharp for Node.js to efficiently resize, convert, and optimize images on the server side.
Ensure proper authentication and authorization when accessing image storage APIs. Use OAuth 2.0 for secure access to cloud storage services.
Adopt a consistent naming convention and directory structure for stored images to facilitate easier management and retrieval.
Monitor image loading performance using tools like Google Lighthouse to identify and address any bottlenecks in image delivery.
Be cautious of CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) issues when serving images from different domains. Configure CORS settings appropriately in your cloud storage.
Implement caching strategies for images using HTTP headers to reduce server load and improve response times for frequently accessed images.

code_examples.description: Example: Asynchronous image upload to AWS S3

code_examples.code:
from PIL import Image

def optimize_image(input_path, output_path):
    with Image.open(input_path) as img:
        img.save(output_path, optimize=True, quality=85)

best_practices: Use multipart uploads for large files to improve reliability and speed.
Implement image resizing on the server-side to serve different sizes based on device type.
Use HTTPS for secure image uploads and downloads.
Set appropriate cache headers for images served from the CDN.
Regularly review and clean up unused images from cloud storage to save costs.
implementation_patterns: Pattern 1: Client-side image compression before upload to reduce file size.
Pattern 2: Server-side processing to generate multiple image sizes for responsive design.
